00001 <?php
00002 /** @file
00003  * This package contains classes for handling database transactions from
00004  * within QueryPath.
00005  *
00006  * The tools here use the PDO (PHP Data Objects) library to execute database
00007  * functions.
00008  *
00009  * Using tools in this package, you can write QueryPath database queries
00010  * that query an RDBMS and then insert the results into the document.
00011  *
00012  * Example:
00013  *
00014  * @code
00015  * <?php
00016  * $template = '<?xml version="1.0"?><tr><td class="colOne"/><td class="colTwo"/><td class="colThree"/></tr>';
00017  * $qp = qp(QueryPath::HTML_STUB, 'body') // Open a stub HTML doc and select <body/>
00018  *  ->append('<table><tbody/></table>')
00019  *  ->dbInit($this->dsn)
00020  *  ->queryInto('SELECT * FROM qpdb_test WHERE 1', array(), $template)
00021  *  ->doneWithQuery()
00022  *  ->writeHTML();
00023  * ?>
00024  * @endcode
00025  *
00026  * The code above will take the results of a SQL query and insert them into a n
00027  * HTML table.
00028  *
00029  * If you are doing many database operations across multiple QueryPath objects,
00030  * it is better to avoid using {@link QPDB::dbInit()}. Instead, you should 
00031  * call the static {@link QPDB::baseDB()} method to configure a single database
00032  * connection that can be shared by all {@link QueryPath} instances.
00033  *
00034  * Thus, we could rewrite the above to look like this:
00035  * @code
00036   * <?php
00037   * QPDB::baseDB($someDN);
00038   *
00039   * $template = '<?xml version="1.0"?><tr><td class="colOne"/><td class="colTwo"/><td class="colThree"/></tr>';
00040   * $qp = qp(QueryPath::HTML_STUB, 'body') // Open a stub HTML doc and select <body/>
00041   *  ->append('<table><tbody/></table>')
00042   *  ->queryInto('SELECT * FROM qpdb_test WHERE 1', array(), $template)
00043   *  ->doneWithQuery()
00044   *  ->writeHTML();
00045   * ?>
00046   * @endcode
00047  *
00048  * Note that in this case, the QueryPath object doesn't need to call a method to
00049  * activate the database. There is no call to {@link dbInit()}. Instead, it checks
00050  * the base class to find the shared database.
00051  *
00052  * (Note that if you were to add a dbInit() call to the above, it would create
00053  * a new database connection.)
00054  *
00055  * The result of both of these examples will be identical.
00056  * The output looks something like this:
00057  * 
00058  * @code
00059  * <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
00060  * <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
00061  * <head>
00062  *  <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8"></meta>
00063  *  <title>Untitled</title>
00064  * </head>
00065  *<body>
00066  *<table>
00067  * <tbody>
00068  *  <tr>
00069  *   <td class="colOne">Title 0</td>
00070  *   <td class="colTwo">Body 0</td>
00071  *   <td class="colThree">Footer 0</td>
00072  *  </tr>
00073  *  <tr>
00074  *   <td class="colOne">Title 1</td>
00075  *   <td class="colTwo">Body 1</td>
00076  *   <td class="colThree">Footer 1</td>
00077  *  </tr>
00078  *  <tr>
00079  *   <td class="colOne">Title 2</td>
00080  *   <td class="colTwo">Body 2</td>
00081  *   <td class="colThree">Footer 2</td>
00082  *  </tr>
00083  *  <tr>
00084  *   <td class="colOne">Title 3</td>
00085  *   <td class="colTwo">Body 3</td>
00086  *   <td class="colThree">Footer 3</td>
00087  *  </tr>
00088  *  <tr>
00089  *   <td class="colOne">Title 4</td>
00090  *   <td class="colTwo">Body 4</td>
00091  *   <td class="colThree">Footer 4</td>
00092  *  </tr>
00093  * </tbody>
00094  *</table>
00095  *</body>
00096  *</html>
00097  * @endcode
00098  *
00099  * Note how the CSS classes are used to correlate DB table names to template
00100  * locations.
00101  *
00102  * 
00103  * @author M Butcher <matt@aleph-null.tv>
00104  * @license http://opensource.org/licenses/lgpl-2.1.php LGPL or MIT-like license.
00105  * @see QueryPathExtension
00106  * @see QueryPathExtensionRegistry::extend()
00107  * @see QPDB
00108  */

00110 /**
00111  * Provide DB access to a QueryPath object.
00112  *
00113  * This extension provides tools for communicating with a database using the 
00114  * QueryPath library. It relies upon PDO for underlying database communiction. This
00115  * means that it supports all databases that PDO supports, including MySQL, 
00116  * PostgreSQL, and SQLite.
00117  *
00118  * Here is an extended example taken from the unit tests for this library.
00119  * 
00120  * Let's say we create a database with code like this:
00121  * @code
00122  *<?php
00123  * public function setUp() {
00124  *   $this->db = new PDO($this->dsn);
00125  *   $this->db->setAttribute(PDO::ATTR_ERRMODE, PDO::ERRMODE_EXCEPTION);
00126  *   $this->db->exec('CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS qpdb_test (colOne, colTwo, colThree)');
00127  *   
00128  *   $stmt = $this->db->prepare(
00129  *     'INSERT INTO qpdb_test (colOne, colTwo, colThree) VALUES (:one, :two, :three)'
00130  *   );
00131  *   
00132  *   for ($i = 0; $i < 5; ++$i) {
00133  *     $vals = array(':one' => 'Title ' . $i, ':two' => 'Body ' . $i, ':three' => 'Footer ' . $i);
00134  *     $stmt->execute($vals);
00135  *     $stmt->closeCursor();
00136  *   }
00137  * }
00138  * ?>
00139  * @endcode
00140  * 
00141  * From QueryPath with QPDB, we can now do very elaborate DB chains like this:
00142  *
00143  * @code
00144  * <?php
00145  * $sql = 'SELECT * FROM qpdb_test';
00146  * $args = array();
00147  * $qp = qp(QueryPath::HTML_STUB, 'body') // Open a stub HTML doc and select <body/>
00148  *   ->append('<h1></h1>') // Add <h1/>
00149  *   ->children()  // Select the <h1/>
00150  *   ->dbInit($this->dsn) // Connect to the database
00151  *   ->query($sql, $args) // Execute the SQL query
00152  *   ->nextRow()  // Select a row. By default, no row is selected.
00153  *   ->appendColumn('colOne') // Append Row 1, Col 1 (Title 0)
00154  *   ->parent() // Go back to the <body/>
00155  *   ->append('<p/>') // Append a <p/> to the body
00156  *   ->find('p')  // Find the <p/> we just created.
00157  *   ->nextRow() // Advance to row 2
00158  *   ->prependColumn('colTwo') // Get row 2, col 2. (Body 1)
00159  *   ->columnAfter('colThree') // Get row 2 col 3. (Footer 1)
00160  *   ->doneWithQuery() // Let QueryPath clean up. YOU SHOULD ALWAYS DO THIS.
00161  *   ->writeHTML(); // Write the output as HTML.
00162  * ?> 
00163  * @endcode
00164  *
00165  * With the code above, we step through the document, selectively building elements
00166  * as we go, and then populating this elements with data from our initial query.
00167  *
00168  * When the last command, {@link QueryPath:::writeHTML()}, is run, we will get output
00169  * like this:
00170  * 
00171  * @code
00172  *   <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
00173  *   <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
00174  *     <head>
00175  *      <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8" />
00176  *      <title>Untitled</title>
00177  *     </head>
00178  *     <body>
00179  *       <h1>Title 0</h1>
00180  *       <p>Body 1</p>
00181  *       Footer 1</body>
00182  *    </html>
00183  * @endcode
00184  *
00185  * Notice the body section in particular. This is where the data has been
00186  * inserted.
00187  *
00188  * Sometimes you want to do something a lot simpler, like give QueryPath a 
00189  * template and have it navigate a query, inserting the data into a template, and
00190  * then inserting the template into the document. This can be done simply with 
00191  * the {@link queryInto()} function.
00192  *
00193  * Here's an example from another unit test:
00194  *
00195  * @code
00196  * <?php
00197  * $template = '<?xml version="1.0"?><li class="colOne"/>';
00198  * $sql = 'SELECT * FROM qpdb_test';
00199  * $args = array();
00200  * $qp = qp(QueryPath::HTML_STUB, 'body')
00201  *   ->append('<ul/>') // Add a new <ul/>
00202  *   ->children() // Select the <ul/>
00203  *   ->dbInit($this->dsn) // Initialize the DB
00204  *   // BIG LINE: Query the results, run them through the template, and insert them.
00205  *   ->queryInto($sql, $args, $template) 
00206  *   ->doneWithQuery()
00207  *   ->writeHTML(); // Write the results as HTML.
00208  * ?>
00209  * @endcode 
00210  *
00211  * The simple code above puts the first column of the select statement
00212  * into an unordered list. The example output looks like this:
00213  *
00214  * @code
00215  * <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
00216  * <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">
00217  *   <head>
00218  *    <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=utf-8"></meta>
00219  *    <title>Untitled</title>
00220  *    </head>
00221  *    <body>
00222  *    <ul>
00223  *    <li class="colOne">Title 0</li>
00224  *    <li class="colOne">Title 1</li>
00225  *    <li class="colOne">Title 2</li>
00226  *    <li class="colOne">Title 3</li>
00227  *    <li class="colOne">Title 4</li>
00228  *    </ul>
00229  *   </body>
00230  * </html>
00231  * @endcode
00232  *
00233  * Typical starting methods for this class are {@link QPDB::baseDB()}, 
00234  * {@link QPDB::query()}, and {@link QPDB::queryInto()}.
00235  *
00236  * @ingroup querypath_extensions
00237  */
00238 class QPDB implements QueryPathExtension {
00239   protected $qp;
00240   protected $dsn;
00241   protected $db;
00242   protected $opts;
00243   protected $row = NULL;
00244   protected $stmt = NULL;

00248   /**
00249    * Create a new database instance for all QueryPath objects to share.
00250    *
00251    * This method need be called only once. From there, other QPDB instances
00252    * will (by default) share the same database instance.
00253    *
00254    * Normally, a DSN should be passed in. Username, password, and db params
00255    * are all passed in using the options array.
00256    *
00257    * On rare occasions, it may be more fitting to pass in an existing database
00258    * connection (which must be a {@link PDO} object). In such cases, the $dsn
00259    * parameter can take a PDO object instead of a DSN string. The standard options
00260    * will be ignored, though.
00261    *
00262    * <b>Warning:</b> If you pass in a PDO object that is configured to NOT throw
00263    * exceptions, you will need to handle error checking differently.
00264    *
00265    * <b>Remember to always use {@link QPDB::doneWithQuery()} when you are done
00266    * with a query. It gives PDO a chance to clean up open connections that may
00267    * prevent other instances from accessing or modifying data.</b>
00268    *
00269    * @param string $dsn
00270    *  The DSN of the database to connect to. You can also pass in a PDO object, which
00271    *  will set the QPDB object's database to the one passed in.
00272    * @param array $options
00273    *  An array of configuration options. The following options are currently supported:
00274    *  - username => (string)
00275    *  - password => (string)
00276    *  - db params => (array) These will be passed into the new PDO object.
00277    *    See the PDO documentation for a list of options. By default, the
00278    *    only flag set is {@link PDO::ATTR_ERRMODE}, which is set to 
00279    *    {@link PDO::ERRMODE_EXCEPTION}.
00280    * @throws PDOException
00281    *  An exception may be thrown if the connection cannot be made.
00282    */
00283   static function baseDB($dsn, $options = array()) {
00284     
00285     $opts = $options + array(
00286       'username' => NULL,
00287       'password' => NULL,
00288       'db params' => array(PDO::ATTR_ERRMODE => PDO::ERRMODE_EXCEPTION),
00289     );
00290     
00291     // Allow this to handle the case where an outside
00292     // connection does the initialization.
00293     if ($dsn instanceof PDO) {
00294       self::$con = $dsn;
00295       return;
00296     }
00297     self::$con = new PDO($dsn, $opts['username'], $opts['password'], $opts['db params']);
00298   }

00301    * 
00302    * This method may be used to share the connection with other, 
00303    * non-QueryPath objects.
00304    */
00305   static function getBaseDB() {return self::$con;}

00316     $this->qp = $qp;
00317     // By default, we set it up to use the base DB.
00318     $this->db = self::$con;
00319   }

00321   /**
00322    * Create a new connection to the database. Use the PDO DSN syntax for a 
00323    * connection string.
00324    *
00325    * This creates a database connection that will last for the duration of 
00326    * the QueryPath object. This method ought to be used only in two cases:
00327    * - When you will only run a couple of queries during the life of the 
00328    *   process.
00329    * - When you need to connect to a database that will only be used for 
00330    *   a few things.
00331    * Otherwise, you should use {@link QPDB::baseDB} to configure a single
00332    * database connection that all of {@link QueryPath} can share.
00333    *
00334    * <b>Remember to always use {@link QPDB::doneWithQuery()} when you are done
00335    * with a query. It gives PDO a chance to clean up open connections that may
00336    * prevent other instances from accessing or modifying data.</b>
00337    *
00338    * @param string $dsn
00339    *  The PDO DSN connection string.
00340    * @param array $options
00341    *  Connection options. The following options are supported:
00342    *  - username => (string)
00343    *  - password => (string)
00344    *  - db params => (array) These will be passed into the new PDO object.
00345    *    See the PDO documentation for a list of options. By default, the
00346    *    only flag set is {@link PDO::ATTR_ERRMODE}, which is set to 
00347    *    {@link PDO::ERRMODE_EXCEPTION}.
00348    * @return QueryPath
00349    *  The QueryPath object.
00350    * @throws PDOException
00351    *  The PDO library is configured to throw exceptions, so any of the 
00352    *  database functions may throw a PDOException.
00353    */
00354   public function dbInit($dsn, $options = array()) {
00355     $this->opts = $options + array(
00356       'username' => NULL,
00357       'password' => NULL,
00358       'db params' => array(PDO::ATTR_ERRMODE => PDO::ERRMODE_EXCEPTION),
00359     );
00360     $this->dsn = $dsn;
00361     $this->db = new PDO($dsn, $this->opts['username'], $this->opts['password'], $this->opts['db params']);
00362     /*
00363     foreach ($this->opts['db params'] as $key => $val)
00364       $this->db->setAttribute($key, $val);
00365     */
00366     
00367     return $this->qp;
00368   }
00369   
00370   /**
00371    * Execute a SQL query, and store the results.
00372    *
00373    * This will execute a SQL query (as a prepared statement), and then store
00374    * the results internally for later use. The data can be iterated using 
00375    * {@link nextRow()}. QueryPath can also be instructed to do internal iteration
00376    * using the {@link withEachRow()} method. Finally, on the occasion that the 
00377    * statement itself is needed, {@link getStatement()} can be used.
00378    *
00379    * Use this when you need to access the results of a query, or when the 
00380    * parameter to a query should be escaped. If the query takes no external 
00381    * parameters and does not return results, you may wish to use the 
00382    * (ever so slightly faster) {@link exec()} function instead.
00383    * 
00384    * Make sure you use {@link doneWithQuery()} after finishing with the database
00385    * results returned by this method.
00386    *
00387    * <b>Usage</b>
00388    * 
00389    * Here is a simple example:
00390    * <code>
00391    * <?php
00392    * QPQDB::baseDB($someDSN);
00393    * 
00394    * $args = array(':something' => 'myColumn');
00395    * qp()->query('SELECT :something FROM foo', $args)->doneWithQuery();
00396    * ?>
00397    * </code>
00398    *
00399    * The above would execute the given query, substituting myColumn in place of 
00400    * :something before executing the query The {@link doneWithQuery()} method
00401    * indicates that we are not going to use the results for anything. This method
00402    * discards the results.
00403    *
00404    * A more typical use of the query() function would involve inserting data
00405    * using {@link appendColumn()}, {@link prependColumn()}, {@link columnBefore()},
00406    * or {@link columnAfter()}. See the main documentation for {@link QPDB} to view
00407    * a more realistic example.
00408    * 
00409    * @param string $sql
00410    *  The query to be executed.
00411    * @param array $args
00412    *  An associative array of substitutions to make.
00413    * @throws PDOException
00414    *  Throws an exception if the query cannot be executed.
00415    */
00416   public function query($sql, $args = array()) {
00417     $this->stmt = $this->db->prepare($sql);
00418     $this->stmt->execute($args);
00419     return $this->qp;
00420   }
00421   
00422   /**
00423    * Query and append the results.
00424    *
00425    * Run a query and inject the results directly into the 
00426    * elements in the QueryPath object.
00427    *
00428    * If the third argument is empty, the data will be inserted directly into
00429    * the QueryPath elements unaltered. However, if a template is provided in 
00430    * the third parameter, the query data will be merged into that template
00431    * and then be added to each QueryPath element.
00432    *
00433    * The template will be merged once for each row, even if no row data is
00434    * appended into the template.
00435    *
00436    * A template is simply a piece of markup labeled for insertion of
00437    * data. See {@link QPTPL} and {@link QPTPL.php} for more information.
00438    *
00439    * Since this does not use a stanard {@link query()}, there is no need
00440    * to call {@link doneWithQuery()} after this method.
00441    *
00442    * @param string $sql
00443    *  The SQL query to execute. In this context, the query is typically a 
00444    *  SELECT statement.
00445    * @param array $args
00446    *  An array of arguments to be substituted into the query. See {@link query()}
00447    *  for details.
00448    * @param mixed $template
00449    *  A template into which query results will be merged prior to being appended
00450    *  into the QueryPath. For details on the template, see {@link QPTPL::tpl()}.
00451    * @see QPTPL.php
00452    * @see QPTPL::tpl()
00453    * @see query()
00454    */
00455   public function queryInto($sql, $args = array(), $template = NULL) {
00456     $stmt = $this->db->prepare($sql);
00457     $stmt->setFetchMode(PDO::FETCH_ASSOC);
00458     $stmt->execute($args);
00459     
00460     // If no template, put all values in together.
00461     if (empty($template)) {
00462       foreach ($stmt as $row) foreach ($row as $datum) $this->qp->append($datum);
00463     }
00464     // Otherwise, we run the results through a template, and then append.
00465     else {
00466       foreach ($stmt as $row) $this->qp->tpl($template, $row);
00467     }
00468     
00469     $stmt->closeCursor();
00470     return $this->qp;
00471   }
00472   
00473   /**
00474    * Free up resources when a query is no longer used.
00475    *
00476    * This function should <i>always</i> be called when the database
00477    * results for a query are no longer needed. This frees up the 
00478    * database cursor, discards the data, and resets resources for future
00479    * use. 
00480    *
00481    * If this method is not called, some PDO database drivers will not allow
00482    * subsequent queries, while others will keep tables in a locked state where
00483    * writes will not be allowed.
00484    *
00485    * @return QueryPath
00486    *  The QueryPath object.
00487    */
00488   public function doneWithQuery() {
00489     if (isset($this->stmt) && $this->stmt instanceof PDOStatement) {
00490       // Some drivers choke if results haven't been iterated.
00491       //while($this->stmt->fetch()) {}
00492       $this->stmt->closeCursor();
00493     }
00494       
00495     unset($this->stmt);
00496     $this->row = NULL;
00497     $this->cycleRows = FALSE;
00498     return $this->qp;
00499   }
00500   
00501   /**
00502    * Execute a SQL query, but expect no value.
00503    * 
00504    * If your SQL query will have parameters, you are encouraged to
00505    * use {@link query()}, which includes built-in SQL Injection 
00506    * protection.
00507    *
00508    * @param string $sql
00509    *  A SQL statement.
00510    * @throws PDOException 
00511    *  An exception will be thrown if a query cannot be executed.
00512    */
00513   public function exec($sql) {
00514     $this->db->exec($sql);
00515     return $this->qp;
00516   }
00517   
00518   /**
00519    * Advance the query results row cursor.
00520    *
00521    * In a result set where more than one row was returned, this will 
00522    * move the pointer to the next row in the set.
00523    *
00524    * The PDO library does not have a consistent way of determining how many
00525    * rows a result set has. The suggested technique is to first execute a
00526    * COUNT() SQL query and get the data from that.
00527    *
00528    * The {@link withEachRow()} method will begin at the next row after the
00529    * currently selected one.
00530    *
00531    * @return QueryPath
00532    *  The QueryPath object.
00533    */
00534   public function nextRow() {
00535     $this->row = $this->stmt->fetch(PDO::FETCH_ASSOC);
00536     return $this->qp;
00537   }
00538   
00539   /**
00540    * Set the object to use each row, instead of only one row.
00541    *
00542    * This is used primarily to instruct QPDB to iterate through all of the 
00543    * rows when appending, prepending, inserting before, or inserting after.
00544    *
00545    * @return QueryPath
00546    *  The QueryPath object.
00547    * @see appendColumn()
00548    * @see prependColumn()
00549    * @see columnBefore()
00550    * @see columnAfter()
00551    */
00552   public function withEachRow() {
00553     $this->cycleRows = TRUE;
00554     return $this->qp;
00555   }

00557   /**
00558    * This is the implementation behind the append/prepend and before/after methods.
00559    *
00560    * @param mixed $columnName
00561    *  The name of the column whose data should be added to the currently selected
00562    *  elements. This can be either a string or an array of strings.
00563    * @param string $qpFunc
00564    *  The name of the QueryPath function that should be executed to insert data
00565    *  into the object.
00566    * @param string $wrap
00567    *  The HTML/XML markup that will be used to wrap around the column data before
00568    *  the data is inserted into the QueryPath object.
00569    */
00570   protected function addData($columnName, $qpFunc = 'append', $wrap = NULL) {
00571     $columns = is_array($columnName) ? $columnName : array($columnName);
00572     $hasWrap = !empty($wrap);
00573     if ($this->cycleRows) {
00574       while (($row = $this->stmt->fetch(PDO::FETCH_ASSOC)) !== FALSE) {
00575         foreach ($columns as $col) {
00576           if (isset($row[$col])) {
00577             $data = $row[$col];
00578             if ($hasWrap) 
00579               $data = qp()->append($wrap)->deepest()->append($data)->top();
00580             $this->qp->$qpFunc($data);
00581           }
00582         }
00583       }
00584       $this->cycleRows = FALSE;
00585       $this->doneWithQuery();
00586     }
00587     else {
00588       if ($this->row !== FALSE) {
00589         foreach ($columns as $col) {
00590           if (isset($this->row[$col])) {
00591             $data = $this->row[$col];
00592             if ($hasWrap) 
00593               $data = qp()->append($wrap)->deepest()->append($data)->top();
00594             $this->qp->$qpFunc($data);
00595           }
00596         }
00597       }
00598     }
00599     return $this->qp;
00600   }
